question: Question_06_(c)
statement:
Consider the curve $x^2+y^3-2xy=0$. Assume that the point \emph{(x,y) =
(1,1)} lies on the curve, and that nearby points on the curve satisfy
\emph{y=f(x)} for some function of \emph{f(x)}.

Approximate \emph{f(1.02)} using the linear approximation of \emph{f(x)}
at \emph{x=1}. State whether you expect this to be an overestimate, or
an underestimate of \emph{f(1.02)}.
sols:
The linear approximation formula is

\[\displaystyle{}L(x)=f(a)+f'(a)(x-a).\]

The number \emph{a} is the value we are approximating around and thus in
our case \emph{a}=1. Since we are trying to approximate f(1.02) we take
\emph{x}=1.02. Using the information from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(a)}{part
(a)} we have that

\[\displaystyle{}f(1.02)\approx{}L(1.02)=f(1)+f'(1)(1.02-1)=1+0(0.02)=1.\]

This gives the estimate that $f(1.02) = 1$. From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(b)}{part
(b)}, the second derivative at x=1 is negative and therefore we see that
the function is concave down at this point. This tells us that points
near x=1 are smaller than what the tangent line predicts and therefore
we expect that our estimate is an overestimate.
hints:
What is the formula for the linear approximation of a function? What is
the a value and what is the x value?

How does the concavity of a function give us information about over and
under estimates? What have we computed in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(a)}{part
(a)} or
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(b)}{part
(b)} that can help us answer this question?
